All families need more space as the kids grow older and have their own friends at home or to stay over. One option is to make more space in your current home by having the loft converted. Your current existing roof space can be converted into that extra room you have always dreamed about. Before the project of converting your loft to a usable space is initiated, several factors need to be considered.

Firstly, the space that is to be used for the project should be properly inspected to ensure that the dimensions of the loft and planned conversion are feasible. The type of conversion that is chosen is generally influenced by the property owner's taste and budget. It is better to initiate a process that is within your budget than to initiate one that exceeds your budget and as a result can not be completed.

Secondly, adequate sound proofing on both the floor and ceiling of your converted loft are essential. This is one thing that many people overlook when constructing the room and only when the job is finished do they realize that the noise generated by someone moving around in the loft above them is much greater than they ever imagined, especially if it is intended as a bedroom, the noise of wind and rain bouncing off the outside roof can be enough to keep even the heaviest of sleepers from having a good night's rest.

Thirdly, getting the amount of light that comes into the loft correct can also be an issue, not enough natural light flooding in through windows can create a gloomy space that no one really wants to claim as their own and too much light can make it very difficult to work or sleep in.

Lastly, a residential loft conversion must have a permanent access staircase. The building regulations require there to be a safe means of escape in the event of fire from any storey with a floor level more than 4.5m above ground level. This is usually achieved by creating an enclosed staircase that will resist fire for at least 30 minutes.

To ensure a smooth loft conversion make sure that you choose a professional loft conversion company that can handle the whole conversion project which will meet your decorative needs. Loft conversions are one of the most popular forms of home improvement in the UK as a result of their numerous perceived benefits. The most obvious benefit of having a loft conversion is the fact that space will be added to your home which is a great solution for a family who needs an extra bedroom, or for someone who wants office space. In fact there are many reasons why people choose to have their loft converted.

Loft conversions have the obvious advantage of providing a great space, they increase the value of the property, they take away the hassle of moving and adding an extra bedroom in the loft is often much cheaper than moving to a house with an extra bedroom in the same area. Loft conversions are also advantageous in comparison with traditional extensions in that they are cheaper to do, they don't take up valuable outside space and you don't have the hassle of sharing your house with tradesman for weeks on end as most of the work is carried out through the roof.

There are various options of loft conversion available and the style you choose will be influenced by the type of house you live in or the area, but rest assured most houses can be done, including those with modern trussed rafter lofts. The various styles for a conversion are roof light, front/side dormer, gable, wrap around, and mansard and rear dormer conversion.

When considering converting your loft, price will obviously be a factor. But you need to be careful here as an inferior job will not add value to your home and may even decrease it. Estate agents view conversions with temporary staircases as adding very little value so ensure that you use a quality company who will advise on permanent staircases. Paying for a professionally designed and constructed job may seem painful now but it will pay back in spades when you come to sell your property.

What are the advantages of a loft conversion over a traditional home extension? Well there are many. Whatever kind of house that you own it is very likely that it will be suitable for a loft project. The cost of a work is also likely to be a lot less than a home extension would be and there is no need to lose valuable outdoor space as well. Most home extensions will require planning permission which can take months whereas a converted loft will probably not. Another major advantage is that conversions often take less time to plan and build which means that you are not sharing your home with local builders for weeks on end.

In order to get the most benefit from your loft conversion, carefully work out the costs to make sure that these do not add up to more than the conversion will be adding to the value of your property. You should also not have your loft converted simply as a way to make your property more valuable â€“ it is important that it is something that adds value to your life as well as the property for it to be truly beneficial.
